derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (denoting misfortune or distress): from Old French meschief, from the verb meschever, from mes- 'adversely' + chever 'come to an end' (from chef 'head')

entry.tran: 恶作剧;淘气;使坏的念头
entry.def: Mischief is playing harmless tricks on people or doing things you are not supposed to do. It can also refer to the desire to do this.

example.ex: The little lad was a real handful. He was always up to mischief...
example.tran: 这个小家伙真是难管教，他总是搞恶作剧。

example.ex: Boys at that age should be able to explore and go off on their own, go on bike rides, get into mischief...
example.tran: 那个年龄的男孩应该可以自己出去闯，也可以骑车出游，还可以调皮捣蛋。

entry.tran: 惹麻烦之事;引起问题的行为；损害;麻烦
entry.def: Mischief is behaviour that is intended to cause trouble for people. It can also refer to the trouble that is caused.

example.ex: The more sinister explanation is that he is about to make mischief in the Middle East again...
example.tran: 更为险恶的解释是，他准备再次在中东地区制造事端。

example.ex: They withdrew their support after the President described the conference as a platform to cause political mischief.
example.tran: 在总统称这次大会是在制造政治事端之后，他们便撤回了对这次会议的支持。

means.word_mean: 1. reckless or malicious behavior that causes discomfort or annoyance in others
2. the quality or nature of being harmful or evil

auth_sentence.content: There was no malice or mischief in his voice.
auth_sentence.res_content: There was no malice or mischief in his voice.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: There was no malice or mischief in his voice.

auth_sentence.content: The motors powering conveyor belts can do similar mischief.

auth_sentence.content: Passion and mischief make British newspapers what they are.
auth_sentence.res_content: Passion and mischief make British newspapers what they are.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Passion and mischief make British newspapers what they are.
